H0.text: The new designs can help save lives in earthquake‑prone areas by allowing buildings to move with the land.

H1.text: The new designs are more attractive, helping people in earthquake‑prone areas by providing visually appealing buildings that can move with the land.

H2.text: The new designs cost less to make, helping people in earthquake‑prone areas by reducing construction costs.

H3.text: The new designs are much taller, helping people by allowing buildings in earthquake‑prone areas to move with the land during seismic events.

A4.text: A properly engineered structure does not necessarily have to be extremely strong or expensive. It has to be properly designed to withstand the seismic effects while sustaining an acceptable level of damage.

A5.text: Seismic design is carried out by understanding the possible failure modes of a structure and providing the structure with appropriate strength, stiffness, ductility, and configuration to ensure those modes cannot occur.

A8.text: Simple structural improvements can be performed by homeowners, reducing the need for expensive engineering solutions.

A9.text: One important tool of earthquake engineering is base isolation, which allows the base of a structure to move freely with the ground.

A10.text: Earthquake engineering structures are those engineered to withstand earthquakes.
